Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: New dwarfing genes to improve yield and abiotic stress tolerance in wheat
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project is the improvement of wheat yields by introducing newly identified dwarfing genes. The currently used dwarfing genes, which were instrumental in bringing about the "green revolution", are at least partly responsible for this bottleneck. These dwarfing genes, present in more than 90% of the wheat varieties grown worldwide, render most of the wheat crop prone to losses due to abiotic (non-living) stresses. This research project will use the products from an NSF-funded academic research to characterize new types of dwarfing genes for wheat, and commercialize selected dwarfing genes around the globe. Outcomes and products from the proposed research project are poised to alleviate the bottleneck created by the currently used dwarfing genes, and have the potential to significantly increase wheat yields, especially under abiotic stress conditions. The research project, while creating a viable commercial product with global appeal, also will contribute positively towards food security in this changing climate.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to further develop and test alternative dwarfing genes to improve wheat yield and abiotic stress tolerance around the globe. Semi-dwarf mutants rht1 and rht2 in wheat are credited for the gene revolution, and are present in more than 90% of the wheat varieties grown worldwide. Their height reduction is due to a reduced production or perception of a plant hormone, gibberellins (GA), which plays a critical role in abiotic stress tolerance. Under abiotic stresses that affect more than 85% of the US and 50% of the world's wheat growing areas, these GA-dwarfs exhibit adverse effects on various agronomic traits including abiotic stress tolerance. The project will characterize newly identified 22 "GA-normal" dwarfing genes for their agronomic advantage over the currently used genes, especially under heat, drought, and salinity stresses with the objective to identify ideal dwarfing gene systems for various wheat growing conditions. The selected dwarfing genes also will be mapped relative to DNA markers for intellectual property protection, and for their transfer to wheat cultivars via marker assisted selection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Research and Development 

Geneshifters has developed technologies to improve abiotic stress tolerance in wheat. Others and Geneshifters have shown that the currently used dwarfing genes have yield penalty even under well-watered/irrigated conditions and this effect is very severe under drought conditions. With the objective to alleviate the ill-effects of the currently used dwarfing genes and to reduce vulnerability due to genetic uniformity caused by the use of the same dwarfing genes all over the world, Geneshifters has developed a line of new dwarfing genes each specifically developed for a particular wheat growing conditions i.e. irrigated, well-watered, drought prone, and saline soils. These new dwarfing genes were developed by exploiting the available natural variation thus their use will not be restricted by regulations typically required for the genetically modified organisms. Since a special emphasis was placed on the complementarity of various new dwarfing genes, it would be possible to pyramid various value added traits present in the new dwarfing genes to further increase their usefulness. For example, various value-added traits present in the new dwarfing genes including  better seedling emergence and vigor, salinity tolerance, drought tolerance, and others can be marketed in different combinations to custom-make dwarfing genes/combinations for various wheat growing areas of the world.

 

Secondly, Geneshifters has developed a novel wheat breeding approach using which a value-added gene such as the new dwarfing genes/gene combinations can be transferred to a desired background to produce a ‘release ready’ wheat cultivar in about two years, which after another two years of field testing and seed increase, can be taken to the farmers’ field in about four years. This will be a tremendous resource to commercialize newly developed dwarfing genes with a potential to develop products for the entire wheat growing areas of the world. In the process of developing these products and approaches, Geneshifters also developed several novel methods to accurately screen wheat lines for various agronomic traits thus the benefits of the project will go way beyond the products mentioned above.

       2. Commercialization and Business Proliferation

Geneshifters has made a significant progress in commercializing these dwarfing technologies. After contacting three major seed companies to commercialize technologies, an agreement was signed with one of the company to market technologies and products in 27 countries including major wheat markets including India and China. Royalties and other profit sharing arrangements have been agreed upon. Exclusive rights to the technologies and products in the 27 countries (excluding Australia, US, Canada, Europe, and many other countries that Geneshifters is planning to target directly) are being negotiated in exchange for a major investment which will help grow the business. Five of the Geneshifters wheat lines carrying two different technologies are under field-testing and seed increase. Because of the NSF funded project, Geneshifters has managed to raise about $400,000 in strategic partnerships without having to give away company equity. Geneshifters is in the process of establishing its own facility containing office, lab, greenhouse, and field operations, all at one place. About five acres of land have been purchased and building approvals have been obtained. The construction has just started.
